name: Josh Terry
tweet: Correct. Critical to remember that both are important.  Many people realize the value of discipline, focus on it, and then lose their capacity for desire.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: There is no discipline without an underlying framework of desire.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Desire is more fundamental to human existence than discipline is.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Feedback develops the motivation muscle.  Enduring lack of feedback develops the discipline muscle.  You need both.

tweet: Controversial way of being:  I know almost none of the words of my favorite song.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: The more at bats you take.  The more at bats you get.  And the better you get at batting.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Take the action that teaches the emotion.  You intellectually understand there’s no need to be afraid.  But the emotional body learns through experience.  So take the action that teaches you what you need to know.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: 80% of people lack motivation because they think there’s nothing to do.  20% of people lack motivation because they think there’s too much too do.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Think back on how much of your life you’ve already forgotten.  Now, you think other people are going to remember a more detailed version than that?

name: Josh Terry
tweet: So if you change your metric of success to becoming the type of person someone else would like to be friends with. Now you’re less affected by your need for friendship and more focused on the thing that will get you a friend.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: The way around this is to change your metric of success to the thing that causes the result you want.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Because what you call success is the same as the result you want. You want a friend so if you get a friend you’ve succeeded. But now you’re wrapped up in the outcome and unattractive.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: This idea applies to money, relationships, business, health, and so many other areas.  But as an example, if you want to be friends with someone it can make you needy in a way that chases away the person you like.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: You have to fix this by figuring out what behavior gets you the result you want and choosing to want that instead of the result.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Wanting something can make it impossible to get it. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: I strongly believe leadership is the scarcest commodity currently available in the world today.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: People who win use:  - Work  &  -Intelligence  Most people get lost forever working on something that will never get them results.  Or spend their time searching for the perfect answer that will solve all their problems and never do the work.  You have to use both.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: People who win implement labor and leverage.  People who lose implement labor without leverage or leverage without labor.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: One of your greatest struggles won’t be to build up your abilities.  It will be to admit to yourself what abilities you don’t have.  And choose to move forward with what you do.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: When two polar ideas work together to create harmonious progress,   we are lost when we adopt one belief to the exclusion of another.  One polarity is the balance between belief and inquiry.   These two actions are not enemies.   They are two sides of the same coin of progress.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Some days I talk to my midjourney bot more than my friends.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: AI is designed to remove work.  But the people who win will be the ones willing to do work…  with it.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Everyone is trying to use AI chatbots to remove the need for work.  The companies that win will be the ones that successfully integrate AI chatbots with their work.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Life requires work from you if you wish to survive.  The longer you fight it the more of a victim you will become.  The more you embrace it the easier the work will be.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you do this, you’ll get to have the more consistent joy of seeing them succeed over the long run instead of the dopamine hit of impressing them with everything you know that won’t help them.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And if you decide to help then set aside all of the things you could tell them that would make you feel cool. And tell them the one thing they could do to move forward.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: So if someone asks you for help, you need to decide if you want to feel good or if you want to help.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But they need one because that’s how many things you can try at the same time to make an improvement.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Tell them one.  Your ego wants to tell them five because it makes you feel smart.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you want to help someone, don’t tell them five things. 🧵👇

tweet: Don’t think, “nobody would know.”  Because it turns you into a child that rebels against external rules.  For example, thinking, “Nobody would know if I gave up on this diet.”  Implies that “other people” wanted you to be on the diet in the first place.  But who’s in charge? And…

tweet: The single greatest hack to reducing social discomfort is realizing that being flawed doesn’t take you out of the game.  Makes you a player of the game.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Most people only move when external circumstances require them to move.  The people who win voluntarily move before external circumstances require them to move.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Many brilliant people struggle because they’ve thought so far ahead they can’t see the path they’re walking on.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: It’s an ability that can be misused. If you can think about the future, you can strategize for a better one, but then you need to set it aside and look at what needs to be done today, or you will fail.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you can think ten steps ahead of other people, but your life is falling apart, it’s because you’re thinking ten steps ahead. 🧵👇

tweet: If you’re a person who comes off as “a bit much” to the people around you there is a:  20% chance you’re a big personality and need to find friends who like that about you.  80% chance you’re in scarcity, people pleasing, or trying to impress people to protect your ego.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: To the master and the cynic…  the next activity is “just another one of those.”  The difference is delight.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: @mrliamrobins Yes, in fact, I usually use gym analogies to make this point. Because everyone agrees overtraining is not good.  It’s obvious because the side effects are more noticeable.  So much harder to get people to understand the same thing applies to the mind.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Most of life is nonsense.  If you make it make 1% more sense for others you win.  Most people don’t try.  If you try 1% harder you win.  Most people only improve when they’re forced to by external circumstance.  If you volunteer 1% more than the rest…  You win.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: There are two ways to make something good.  1. Analyze what is best, create based on that analysis, and repeat.  2. Create something first, analyze what you’ve done, and do it again.  Almost all advice on niching recommends option one. Because most people don’t have creative…

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Personalities high in openness create first and analyze second.  Personalities low in openness analyze first and create second.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you get your life together, you’re eventually going to have to choose how much responsibility you will volunteer to take on.  The answer isn’t “the most you think you can.”  It’s not “the most you can.”  It’s, “the most you can while maintaining enough of a gap below max…

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But assume that it’s something that should be avoided at all costs and you’ll be distracted forever by the fear of it.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Failure is inevitable. And it’s something you can deal with.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: The people who are distracted by this fear fall behind. And the ones who don’t let it bother them, or embrace it, race ahead.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: It’s the fear of a thing that can’t be stopped, that happens to everyone.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And if you fail often enough in the right ways a strange thing will happen. You’ll become successful.  Because the fear of failure is more dangerous than failure itself.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: There’s no escape from it.  No matter how incredible you are or how rich you become, you will fail.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you want to be successful, you need to know failure is an inevitable part of life. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Put yourself on a path to accelerated growth by doing the thing that makes you want to do another thing.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Bring people into your life that don’t require you to explain yourself.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Almost made a tweet about privilege, then deleted it.  Which is what most reasonable people are doing.  This is why the crazy is loud.  Could I be convinced to talk about it? Sure.  It's just more useful to get back to work.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But when we do that we always misjudge and slowly wear ourselves down. Instead, learn to enjoy a boring recuperative life that makes you strong and then dive into the crazy that makes you stronger.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: People want activities to be just right. And something that’s too boring or mundane is intolerable so most people seek to be ‘just stressed enough.’

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Both of these make you different from normal because most of us seek the middle ground.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And then to explore the mundane is to realize that you’re not really all that, you’re weak and barely hanging on to this life thing because it’s hard. So you voluntarily do wild things sometimes and then do quiet restful things that are way below your competency range.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Because most people wait until external circumstances force the weird or difficult upon them.   To do it preemptively is to explore a different way to live.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: To occasionally push yourself to something weird gives you a life experience that’s not normal.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: There’s value in moving back and forth between the extreme and the mundane.  🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: You need to do what you like or learn to like what you do.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: The people I know that wake up early to workout mostly like waking up early.  The people I know that are super into anything they say they’re super disciplined about, like the thing they’re into.  Which means you probably need to do what you like or learn to like what you do.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Animals use play as a way to iterate faster.  Play creates a box (a game with rules) of actions that can be experimented on without risk.  This is why play is essential.  Every skill based activity can be learned faster and at a higher level when it’s learned playfully.  https://t.co/E4ein8Pt0R

name: Josh Terry
tweet: @AmyZenone Thank you!

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you want freedom, embrace a responsibility others won’t accept.  If you want to suffer less, become okay with experiencing suffering.  And if you want more stuff, learn to do more with what you have.  Many solutions are found by diving into the discomfort you want to avoid.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: The freedom of choice brings with it the burden of choice.  - Freedom give you an abundance of options.  - But with that abundance comes the necessity of narrowing down the options and picking some or letting them destroy you.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Why is everyone drawing verification check artwork now? Did I miss a piece of internet history?

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you do something big that you care so much about, that if you mess it up it will physically harm you, or you will be so disappointed that you can't recover or learn from it then it's not a useful thing to fail at.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: The idea of picking a failure that won't break you is an important one.  🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Every juvenile mammal learns through play.  Play is critical to education and survival.  But adults tend to stop playing.  So what makes you think play itself isn’t fundamentally useful?  If you stop playing you’ll stop learning.  https://t.co/gaKwDdVHLI

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Pride is deadly. It's the belief that you are more significant than you are in a way that twists the fabric of reality.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: People are so afraid of feeling pride that they destroy their self-worth and belief in their ability to achieve to avoid it. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: History teaches you form and context. It gives you language and a toolkit.  But if you find yourself trying to build a toolkit for a living you aren’t creating anything new.  And somebody else built it better.  Make your own house and use your own design. Think forward.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Think thoughts you wouldn't normally think if you'd like to get results you wouldn't normally get.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: @amasad As am I.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you have a long term goal and you’re not reaching it then you need to decide if your vision for the future is helpful. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: The fear of failure is:  The fear of something that happens to everyone.  That cannot be avoided.  And can help you grow.  (Also, it can destroy you, which makes it complicated.)

name: Josh Terry
tweet: @glory__na Yes.  And the push yourself sets people into the mindset of trying too hard.  Ah the webs we weave.  Left ditch? Right ditch?

name: Josh Terry
tweet: The "push yourself" narrative got mixed up with the "you need to try" narrative.  You need to try often. And push yourself occasionally.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Don’t let people use you without reward or recognition. But learn to be useful and to insist that you receive the respect and admiration that you’ve rightly earned. And you will find yourself wanting to help more people tomorrow.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Learning to be selfish in a healthy way is about protecting yourself so that you can create enough abundance that you’re overflowing with good things and others benefit from being around you.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But don’t get so lost in protecting yourself that you forget how rewarding it is to help others.  We all want to feel as though we did something good in the world. And the best way to do good is to be useful.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: You want people to use you.  You just don’t want to feel used.  You want to be useful and then be rewarded for that usefulness.  You have to set boundaries to stop others from taking too much.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you want to feel like you matter then remember this. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Acting on desire is the fastest way to act. And taking action is the fastest way to learn.  Disclaimer: If you're doing lots of stuff and keep making stupid mistakes, you should probably stop and think for a bit.

tweet: Sit down in the middle of your room.  Quiet your mind.  And ask yourself the question, “What is the smallest realistic action that will get the biggest result?”  And then wait.  When you come up with an answer, get up and go take that action.  Go back to your room.  Repeat.

tweet: Anyone else freak out because everything is okay?  More terrifying, things are going great?  Happens to me all the time.  The brain likes to default to problems.  When you remove the problem, if you don’t rewire your thinking…  The absence of the problem is just another problem.

tweet: What if you improved life by making it smaller? Chasing your dreams is great and you should do it. But if it's crushing you then obviously there's more to the story.

tweet: When we think about making our lives better we often think about chasing our dreams. But if you've been chasing your dreams and life isn't better then there's something else to do. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Make stuff in a way that suits your psychology and uses your talents.  Don’t give up but let go at the same time.  Discipline and push yourself in the way that helps you.  Not the way a narrative (recipe) tells you that you should.  Give yourself the chance to learn and grow.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Eight sounds like a nice round number. You’ll never get everything you need from a Twitter thread.  But the bonus thing I’ll say is that if you are looking for the recipe you won’t find it.  Because the recipe is being cool with no recipe.  Just kidding one more tweet below.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: 8. I followed my desire and curiosity.  I didn’t niche (at first).  I didn’t batch (at first).  I made cool stuff I wanted to make in a way that made me want to make more of it.

tweet: @khemaridh Doing stuff I should have found a way to get somebody else to do.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: tfw when you think you need to get a whole bunch of things done,   when you know you'll do them ineffectively,  and then realize you can get somebody else to do it.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And then you’ll have found the answer you can’t be found by searching for the answer.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: You’ll develop the belief that, even though you don’t know everything and you never will, you are a capable person who can keep going.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And if you can do this, then you will develop certainty. You will develop confidence that doesn’t depend on having the right answer.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Learn how to move forward even when you’re feeling unsure.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And if you’re looking for the answer that fixes your life, you’ll never find it. Because the answer is to learn to live with the questions.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Stop looking for the answer that solves everything. Because the best information gives you more questions than answers. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But if you take responsibility for the person you are today and give yourself the task that will make you burn brighter tomorrow you will become unstoppable.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And to consider yourself any more or less than you are right now is to add the wrong fuel to your fire.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But if you give it the fuel of achievable tasks and space between those jobs for the heat to flow upward it burns brighter and turns into a flame that can’t be put out.  You are that spark.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you don’t give yourself the oxygen of effort and rest it will burn out. If you give it the weight of too many tasks you’ll smother it.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Imagine your potential as a tiny spark in the dark. And it’s your job to make it burn brighter. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Never underestimate the value of…  sleeping for two hours   completing the task that would’ve taken two and a half hours  in a half hour   at a higher level of quality and while in a good mood.  Same amount of time, very different final result.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you’re a music lover,   try not listening to music for a week or two,  then put your headphones on,   pick a special track,   and lay back as a love for humanity washes over your entire existence.

tweet: These are the kind of tweets twitter was made for.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Good intention and honesty alone can both turn you into an over controlling monster. Use them together and they guide you in a healthy direction.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And honesty gives you strength, stability, and stops you from using your good intentions as an excuse to do evil things.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But if you believe in honesty and trying to make things better then the two values balance each other.  Good intention gives you enthusiasm, likability, power, and direction to your honesty.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And if you only believe in having a positive intention you can easily convince yourself to lie, cheat, and steal because you think you're a “good guy” doing it for the “right reasons.”

name: Josh Terry
tweet: I believe that honesty and positive intention are the key to getting good results.  Because if you only believe in honesty, you can turn it into a weapon that destroys and manipulates. You can insult and hurt others way more than a liar could. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: I think the “read” notification on messages might be the dumbest invention.  It makes everyone worse.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And learn to give yourself smaller doses of the thing that frightens you most and you  learn to be stronger than the thing you fear.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Don’t think something is impossible because of what it is, but instead, how much it is.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: So if you can break a fear into smaller pieces, even if it’s your greatest fear, it becomes something you can deal with.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: So if something feels impossible to deal with, it’s not because you’re afraid of that specific thing. It’s because you’re afraid of that thing in that amount.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Every fear can be overcome. But not every amount. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Remember, some people’s regular sober day is your psychedelic mushroom trip.  Yes, people’s internal worlds are that different.  It’s good to remember for perspective.  And no, you won’t be as functional as they are if you decide to live on mushrooms.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: @marenaltman I feel enlightened. You honor us with this art. Also I did abs yesterday and laughing hurts. This might be my favorite yet.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: The next generation gets to have the chance to do something different. But they have to remember to embody some of the strength and ways of being that their parents had in order to get them there.  If not, the cyclical rhyme of history will begin and it won’t be pretty.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And within every generation there were parents before them that sacrificed options but also solved problems creatively to be strong enough to give their children better options.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But we have to tap into the infinite nature of who a person can be to become a king, a warrior, a magician, a lover, an artist, a friend. We have to adapt and learn nuance.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: We have to control it because if we try to be everything we will fail. We have to sacrifice options and potential future selves in order to do what needs to be done and become someone worth being.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Infinity lies within us all. And we have to both control it and tap into it.  🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And then, to choose to take on responsibility for directing those actions and dealing with the consequences.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: That you have power over your own actions.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: To become an adult is to understand and accept that actions have consequences, both positive and negative. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: @TheLordOfTongs Good point. “Let’s get rid of the enemy we know. It will be so much better that way…”

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Sometimes the way through fear is through understanding that the person you're with is dangerous enough to handle you at your most fearful.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: So accept the other person's fears completely. Embrace them as they are. Don't invalidate them. But let your own emotions of confidence and comfort with the situation be visible and recognized by the person you're with. And give them an opportunity to mirror that strength.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And you as a fellow human are probably the most dangerous thing in the room. But you're also on that person's team. And when we feel afraid, we want to know that the people around us are strong enough to handle whatever may come our way including ourselves if we lose control.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: It's easy to assume that when someone is afraid you should reduce the number of visibly dangerous things around them.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Making yourself small is not the answer.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you're having a moment with someone and that other person is feeling fear and you want to help them work through it. Don't try to lessen their fears by making yourself appear weaker. Accept their fear and provide them with strength. 🧵👇

tweet: @vanadergrowth @Maslowlab Thank you. I agree. Would love to make more like this.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Idk why I’m rebelling against threadboys. I’m one of them.  But nevertheless, this is my threadboy rebellion.  Stay tuned for more threads.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: 6. No one said this on the Tim Ferriss Podcast. But because I listened, I learned it.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: 5. That's what podcasts are for.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: 4. Sometimes it comes from dancing with a piece of information to fully integrate and understand it.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: 3. Because not all learning comes from data recorded in simple bullet point tweet threads.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: 2. There is information that you can summarize. But it won't teach you what you want to know.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: 1. You can't make a tweet thread that bullet points 600 podcasts.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: I listened to every episode of the @tferriss podcast for years.  Here's what I learned.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: A collaboration with @Maslowlab . Thank you for making such a cool video.  https://t.co/AE71RVisBg

name: Josh Terry
tweet: if you think the solution is one thing and the problem is your life, you’re probably wrong

name: Josh Terry
tweet: @2reece3 Absolutely

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Suffering and comfort make equally stupid religions.  Don’t fetishize one human experience above all else.  That’s just called addiction.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Be willing to embrace the wave when it comes, and then enjoy the sun when it shines.  This tweet is not about the beach.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: How you navigate the world is defined by how you remember it.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Be smart, work hard, and optimize for luck. But always take into account your specific situation. Don’t just do whatever people say is the best thing to do unless you judge it to be the right thing to do today.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: You have to learn from others, but don’t let the fact that they’ve succeeded where you haven’t make you think you should do everything they say.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: So when they tell you what to do, they don’t realize the advice they gave only worked for them because many other things went right.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But they don’t realize they were lucky. They only see the hard work they put into something.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Many intelligent people have won in life because they were smart and lucky.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Be careful not to take advice from people just because they’re successful. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you are an overly nice person, and you are both offending and apologizing to more people.  And the number of friends you have is growing or your current relationships are deepening.  You’re probably on the right track.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Thank you for having me on!

name: Josh Terry
tweet: The less you feel like you have the more you feel like you should listen to someone else.  The more you do that, the less you make choices that are right for you.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But it makes it impossible to stick to any one task because as soon as you take advice from the first confident person the next one appears and you change your path.  And you ignore your unique talents because you want to be like everyone else.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And people that are confident in their opinions seem like they have a lot to give.  And since we feel like we don’t have enough, we do everything the abundant people say so we can get what they have.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you’re a self-doubter and struggling then taking advice from too many people might be keeping you down.  When life isn’t going well you get a sensation called scarcity, the feeling that there isn’t enough to go around. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: I’m not sure, but it seems like @elonmusk is into:  Helping people walk using brain signals. Getting rid of child pornography. Accelerating sustainable energy. Helping internet not go down. Getting to mars.  Seems cool to me.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: I believe that if we can do this more often in the small things, it will teach us. It will make us more knowledgeable and it will teach us how to go after the big things.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: How often do we pick a job to do today that makes us feel like we've really accomplished something? Or have a conversation about the thing we want to talk about?

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But how often do we plan for the specific concert that's on our bucket list and go to work with a smile the next day even though we're tired? Or plan a specific meal that has something we've never tried, that will be fun and make us feel good?

name: Josh Terry
tweet: It's a skillset to go after what you want.  And most of us don't do it often enough. We have a couple specific dreams we're working toward, and then we occasionally give up, blow off steam, and go after something that makes us feel terrible the next day. 🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Right now, we live in a time period where there are less personal connections than ever. Which means we need them more than ever.  So go be the person who starts something.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Almost anyone has the power to build connections. But you have to be willing to do what’s required to make it happen.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: But if you understand that it’s work, and you build things that help people come together, if you’re willing to take the risk that maybe nobody will show up, and you take the time to say “hey, I like you. let’s be friends.” then you can have what you want.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And if you expect it to occur naturally then you’ll live a lonely life.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Surrounding yourself with the people you want in your life isn’t something that happens on accident.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: If you want friends. Remember that you need to make them.  🧵👇

name: Josh Terry
tweet: @khemaridh Fun article. I’m getting more and more amazed at people’s definitions of ‘enough.’  Used to be a million.  Now it’s a million a year.  And an excellent excuse to remain sad for a lifetime.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: @KhansTips It’s strange, going meta can be incredibly useful and incredibly useless depending on how it’s done. I think it’s just a matter of whether going meta is adding to the global consciousness or or diluting the soup of the product…this tweet also might be too meta.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: One of the most predictable ways to build an audience online  is to make content about how to build an audience online.  The internet is becoming an attention ponzi scheme.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Chat gpt is becoming more and more like me and I don’t like it.  It keeps telling me how important context is.  I know, chat gpt.  That’s why I asked you. You are the context of billions of conversations. That was the context I wanted.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: I will get consistent with that newsletter :) I’m committed!

name: Josh Terry
tweet: High praise to be included with people I greatly admire. Thank you.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: @nagotejena @naval @visualizevalue @jackbutcher @zachpogrob Thank you!

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Artists die poor because society takes 10-100yrs to process new material, isolate the valuable parts, reverse engineer them, and create sellable products based on the fundamentals the artist introduced into that society.  AI can do that reverse engineering in seconds.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And the more practice you give yourself deciding that your work is done the more decisive you will become.  And the more decisive you are the more energy you will have.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Not the occasional wrong decision.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: And the more you own the fact that you have to make a decision and practice making decisions quickly. The more energetic, confident, and capable you will become. Because the indecisiveness itself and your fear that you’ll make the wrong choice is the real enemy.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: You will always have to decide at some point that something is finished. You have to decide that you’re right or wrong and move on. You have to listen to a piece of advice and choose to take it or leave it.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Time spent wondering whether or not you’re doing everything you need to do is time spent not doing what needs to be done.

name: Josh Terry
tweet: Not to mention that it’s a waste of time.
